sect3.title: Overview

figure.title: Applying example for the Sparkle filter

sect3.para: This filter adds sparkles to your image. It uses the lightest points determined by the Luminosity threshold. It is difficult to predict the location of the sparkles. You can add white dots on your image where you want the sparkles to appear.

sect3.title: Activating the Filter
sect3.para:
This filter is found in the main menu under
Filters Light and Shadow Sparkleâ€¦ .

listitem.para: If checked, the settings are interactively updated in the preview area. Scroll bars allow you to move the image, but you can also drag the visible area with your pointing device.
The higher the threshold, the more areas will get sparkles.
This adjusts the strenght of the flare.
This determines the length of the rays. Reducing this value causes small spikes to decrease first.

The number of starting points for spikes. This value is used for both the number of big spikes and small spikes. When this value is odd, small spikes are opposite the big ones. When it is even, big spikes are opposite another big spike.

This sets the angle of the first big spike. If set to -1, the angle is chosen at random. If a spot has several pixels within the Luminosity threshold, each of them will generate a sparkle. If the angle is positive, they will all be superimposed. With -1, each sparkle will have a random rotation resulting in numerous thin spikes.
This option determines the number of sparkles on your image. It indicates the percentage of all possible sparkles that will be preserved.
When you increase transparency, sparkles become more transparent and the layer beneath becomes visible. If there is no other layer, sparkle saturation decreases.
This sets how much the hue of the sparkles should be changed randomly.
This sets how much the saturation of the sparkles should be changed randomly.
If set, the central pixels of the sparkle keep the luminosity of the brightest pixel. This reduces the brightness.
Instead of selecting the brightest pixels in the image, Sparkle will select the darkest ones, resulting in dark sparkles.
When enabled, instead of creating sparkles on the brightest pixels, this creates an image border made up of sparkles.
This selects the color used for the central pixels of the sparkles. This color will be added in Screen mode (Multiply if Inverse is checked). Natural color is the color of the pixel in the image.
